etymology.description: 官 (official) + 二 (second) + 代 (generation) = second generation of officials (children of officials).
etymology.interpretation: Refers to the offspring of government officials, highlighting lineage as the source of status. In public discourse it can imply access to connections, privilege, or influence.

parts.english: government official; public office; officialdom; organ (TCM)
generation; era; to substitute; to replace

examples.chinese: 许多人用官二代指官员的子女(許多人用官二代指官員的子女)。
examples.pinyin: Xǔduō rén yòng guān’èrdài zhǐ guānyuán de zǐnǚ.
examples.english: Many people use guan’erdai to refer to the children of officials.

examples.chinese: 有人认为官二代容易获得资源和机会(有人認為官二代容易獲得資源和機會)，也有人强调不能以偏概全(也有人強調不能以偏概全)。
examples.pinyin: Yǒurén rènwéi guān’èrdài róngyì huòdé zīyuán hé jīhuì, yě yǒurén qiángdiào bùnéng yǐpiān gàiquán.
examples.english: Some think guan’erdai easily obtain resources and opportunities, while others stress you shouldn’t generalize.

examples.chinese: 他不是官二代，却靠自身努力考入名校(他不是官二代，卻靠自身努力考入名校)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bù shì guān’èrdài, què kào zìshēn nǔlì kǎorù míngxiào.
examples.english: He isn’t a guan’erdai, yet he got into a top school through his own effort.
